Your May 12 front-page article ''Mini-Vans Facing a Midlife Crisis at Age 14'' showed an example of American consumers being led to make shallow choices.

The mini-van to some means responsibility, and a sport utility vehicle portrays freedom; in actuality they mean neither. A responsible person would consider the effects of driving either kind of gas-guzzler, both of which contribute to carbon monoxide emissions and other greenhouse gases.
And the ''freedom'' of a sport utility vehicle? Where is the freedom in more pavement, more traffic jams, more pollution and more money spent on gas, repairs and insurance?

More people need to choose alternative transportation. Whether by bike, bus, light rail or car-sharing, we can contribute to a healthier environment as well as save money and have more time spent out of traffic jams.
